description:
Rhinolophus hipposideros, commonly known as the lesser horseshoe bat, is a small species of bat belonging to the family Rhinolophidae. It is found across Europe, North Africa, and parts of Asia.

The lesser horseshoe bat is characterized by its distinctive horseshoe-shaped nose leaf, which it uses for echolocation. It has small, rounded ears and a compact, furry body that measures around 4-5 inches in length. The species typically weighs between 5-10 grams.

These bats are primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of small insects such as moths, flies, and beetles. They are adept at maneuvering in tight spaces and can often be found roosting in caves, old buildings, and other sheltered areas.

The lesser horseshoe bat is known for its social behavior, often forming large colonies during the breeding season. Females give birth to a single pup, which they care for and nurture until it is able to fly and forage independently.

The species is considered vulnerable in parts of its range due to habitat loss and disturbance of its roosting sites. Conservation efforts are underway to protect and maintain the populations of this unique and fascinating small bat.
